instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used to discriminate biomass pellets?
Output: Laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) was used to analyze the spectra of biomass pellets.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used discriminate biomass pellets?
Output: PCA, PLS-DA, SVM, RBFNN, and ELM were used as spectral feature processing methods to discriminate biomass pellets.

instruction: What metric was chosen discriminate biomass pellets and how far can this metric go in discriminating biomass pellets?
Output: The metric chosen to discriminate biomass pellets was the RBFNN model. This model had an average recognition accuracy of 100% in the calibration set and 96.88% in the prediction set, indicating a high level of accuracy in discriminating biomass pellets.

instruction: What did the researchers use machine learning models to discriminate biomass pellets?
Output: The researchers used machine learning models, specifically Principal Component Analysis (PCA), Partial Least Squares Discrimination Analysis (PLS-DA), Support Vector Machines (SVM), Radial Basis Function Neural Network (RBFNN), and Extreme Learning Machine (ELM), to discriminate biomass pellets.

instruction: How effective was the laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) coupled with chemometrics methods in discriminating biomass pellets and selecting the category with better combustion performance ?
Output: The laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy (LIBS) coupled with chemometrics methods was found to be effective in discriminating biomass pellets and selecting the category with better combustion performance. Past study used various chemometrics methods such as Principal Component Analysis (PCA), Partial Least Squares Discrimination Analysis (PLS-DA), Support Vector Machines (SVM), Radial Basis Function Neural Network (RBFNN), and Extreme Learning Machine (ELM) to quantitatively distinguish biomass pellets. Among these methods, the RBFNN model showed a reliable discrimination power, achieving an average recognition accuracy of 100% in the calibration set and 96.88% in the prediction set. The results also demonstrated that LIBS combined with chemometrics methods could accurately distinguish rice husk, which has relatively poor combustion performance, from wood biomass pellets. Therefore, the study concluded that LIBS coupled with chemometrics methods could be a novel and reliable approach for discriminating biomass pellets and selecting the category with better combustion performance.
